<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>I’m home in Western Massachusetts to see my parents for the weekend, but with all due respect to them, the real party here is the #foliage.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">At first glance, the sea of yellow, orange, red, and brown might seem like a random medley of colors...but it’s not. When chlorophyll abandons a tree in the autumn, it leaves behind a mix of other pigments that are distinct from one species to the next.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The sugar maple, which rules the fall foliage world in North America, glows a brilliant orange. Dogwoods turn reddish-purple. Beech and hickory trees get their yellow on. And oak leaves—well, most of the poor fellows fade to brown before they become raking fodder.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I like to think of it as each tree leaving its individual signature on nature's canvas before retiring for the winter.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>
</div>

</tr>

<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers With...Broadway's Jordan Fisher
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/icebreakers-with-broadway-s-jordan-fisher?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Icebreakers With...Broadway's Jordan Fisher" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/1ba40492ff948b1eaefd5ad56f85a02c9861468e-4240x2832.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Jordan Fisher</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Jordan Fisher has appeared in TV shows since 2009, but the actor got his big break on Broadway in 2016 with a role in <em>Hamilton</em>. In December 2019, Jordan was selected to play the lead in <em>Dear Evan Hansen </em>and then...well...no one got to play any theater roles, anywhere. Now, Jordan will finally get the chance to wear his cast on Broadway starting December 11.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We caught up with Jordan to see how he’s feeling now that Broadway’s back.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Tell us what it means to be heading back to live theater again with <em>Dear Evan Hansen</em>. Do you think anything will be different after being away for so long?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Just to be in the theater again...I didn't anticipate the range of emotions that I would feel walking into a theater. I missed that energy. So I'm thrilled to be able to take the stage again for <em>Dear Evan Hansen</em> and wear that polo and wave through windows all over again.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What are the top three songs you've been listening to right now?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I've been listening to a lot of <a href="https://open.spotify.com/artist/5rwUYLyUq8gBsVaOUcUxpE?si=gn4pq5CgTbi-6MwuCrc2ZA" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Lawrence</a>. Their new album, <em>Hotel TV</em>, just came out, and they have a song on there called “False Alarms” that I've been listening to a lot. I've also been listening to “<a href="https://open.spotify.com/track/6NoTgpadvWX0qKEK6aJYsg?si=9b8ef6e9510d47e5" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">I Feel It</a>” by Jon Bellion, and “<a href="https://open.spotify.com/track/15qKrPi4Kg0z7g9HlwWyeb?si=527dad8c9b324324" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Jackie</a>” by Bas with J-Cole & Lil Tjay.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Speaking of music, what's the hardest thing you've ever had to sing?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The hardest song any artist ever has to sing ever is the US national anthem. That will always be the answer. It's just very difficult. It requires a lot of you. It takes a lot of energy and it's usually a cappella, and there is very, very minimal room for error.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>You’re 27 now, what are some things you wish you knew when you were 20 years old?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Everything that I know now. It's funny because everybody is either in a rush to grow up or doesn't want to grow up at all. And I feel I'm somewhere in the middle. I think that my appreciation for time as a kind of currency has grown as I age. But at the end of the day, I would never go back and tell my past self anything because everything that's happened in my life has happened for a reason. This is what has led me to this point. And I'm very happy with my life.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So, I think if I had to go back in time and tell my past self anything, it would be like, *fist bump* “Let's just keep going.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.</em></p>
</div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse" width="100%">
<tr>

<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
I Don't Have Anything to Do At Work. Should I Leave?
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/undefined?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make it work image " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I started a new job last month and they haven’t given me much guidance on what my role is. Most days I’m twiddling my thumbs for eight hours. Is it worth sticking it out to see if the environment changes?—Lily, Baltimore</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I read <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/12/americans-quit-their-jobs-at-a-record-rate-in-august?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">somewhere</a> this week that 4.3 million people (and presumably 8.6 million thumbs) quit their jobs in the US this August. While “sticking it out” may not be trending right now, that doesn’t necessarily mean you should be in a rush to join the exodus.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Short of identifying something toxic or egregiously incompatible, a month is a pretty short time period to make a judgment call one way or another about a job. There’s a decent chance your boss is trying to ease you in and doesn’t realize how truly idle you are. It’s equally possible that you’re simply experiencing lackluster onboarding and/or management. Either way, you’ll need to take the reins. You’re 30 days in—what do you expect to be doing in 60 days? 90 days? Reflect on what attracted you to this job. If there’s not a clear path to you doing those things in a reasonable timeframe, it may be time to look elsewhere.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">As you seek out more to do, be careful not to get yourself saddled with “busy work.” It’s always easier to add to your plate than to take away, so view this as an opportunity to handpick high-value tasks that interest you. Remember that a valuable work experience doesn’t always mean you’re churning out high priority emails. Especially early on in your career, it’s important to consider if there are experiences (and people) worth learning from.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Bottom line</strong>: Sticking it out in hopes that the environment changes isn’t the answer, but taking advantage of a chance to mold your own environment is a rare opportunity that may pay off down the line. Just promise us you’ll never get <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W6xFS-WhcRc" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">too busy to twiddle your own thumbs</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Write in here</a>. And remember, we're also compiling work horror stories ahead of Halloween. If you've got a good one, <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/XNKgx2M7?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">share it here</a>.</em></p>
</div>

<td align="left" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 10px 0px; word-break: break-word;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #ffe62e 25%, #0f9046); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Toys Will Be Toys
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/the-toy-industry-is-becoming-more-gender-neutral?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Toy Story dad hands Woody to daughter" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=375 src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-15/image-0de3da6f2944c717f2c3630413db8f393daa66b6-590x330-gif/giphy-1.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Toy Story dad hands Woody to daughter" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-15/image-0de3da6f2944c717f2c3630413db8f393daa66b6-590x330-gif/giphy-1.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Giphy</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Just over a week ago, California passed a law that requires large department stores to create <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2021/10/10/california-mandate-gender-neutral-toy-sections/6082593001/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">gender-neutral sections</a> with a “reasonable selection” of nongendered toys and child care items.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px"><li>
<span><strong>To be clear: </strong></span><span>Stores can still have boys’ and girls’ sections, but they </span><span><em>also</em></span><span> need to have an unlabeled section.</span>
</li></ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The woke and the anti-woke are duking it out in Facebook comments over CA’s new bill, the first of its kind passed in the US, with supporters saying that it helps counter gender stereotypes and opponents arguing it’s government overreach. But the fact is...the toy industry has been moving toward gender neutrality for the better part of the past decade—without lawmakers forcing its hand.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">On the retail side:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li>
<span>Toys“R”Us (which is back from the dead FYI) announced it was </span><span><a href="https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/11/23/toys-r-us-gender-neutral_n_8626842.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">doing away</a></span><span> with gender signage in its stores in 2013 and deleted the “boy” and “girl” filters from its website in 2015.</span>
</li>
<li><span>Target nixed gendered aisles and labels in 2015.</span></li>
<li><span>Ditto for Walmart’s aisles, except you can still search by gender online.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Even if stores leave their “girl” and “boy” signs up...they may have a hard time sorting toys into binary aisles:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li>
<span>Mattel has a line of </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/25/arts/mattel-gender-neutral-dolls.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">genderless Barbies</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
<li>
<span>Easy Bake Oven started selling a silver and black version after a </span><span><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2012/12/18/living/hasbro-easy-bake-oven/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew#:~:text=The%2013%2Dyear%2Dold%20launched,other%20boys%20from%20using%20them." class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">viral petition</a></span><span> in 2012 derided the “girly” color scheme.</span>
</li>
<li>
<span>Hasbro launched a Potato Head family set that lets kids mash together </span><span><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/25/business/mr-potato-head-hasbro-gender-neutral/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nontraditional parent</a></span><span> combos.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">The latest brand to board the genderless toy train is Lego</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Lego announced this week that it would completely scrap gendering its little blocks—which already don’t discriminate between the bottoms of feet—through marketing efforts or otherwise. It based that decision on a big survey that showed girls “remain held back by society’s ingrained gender stereotypes as they grow older.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Parents of 6-to-14-year-olds took the first half of the survey, and their kids took the second half, which led to some <a href="https://www.npr.org/2021/10/12/1045244110/lego-toys-survey-gender-bias-stereotypes?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">eye-opening learnings</a> around ingrained gender stereotypes, like:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>76% of parents said they’d encourage their sons to play with Legos, but just 24% would recommend Legos to their daughters.</span></li>
<li><span>71% of boys worry they’ll be made fun of for playing with feminine-coded toys, compared to 42% of girls for masculine-coded toys.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">These discrepancies don’t stop at the toy aisle. Parents said they’re more likely to encourage girls to cook and bake than boys, and more likely to encourage boys to play sports than girls.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Zoom out: </strong>For proponents of gender neutrality in the toy aisle, this stereotyping of what a “girl” and “boy” can <em>do</em> limits what kids think they can <em>be</em> when they grow up.<em>—JW</em></p>
</div>

Open House
</h1>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section dedicated to showcasing what Kanye doesn’t want anymore. We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess the price.</p>
<img class="img-responsive" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-15/image-cbd6102ba085039018cdb82c46292938cffe6871-512x274-gif/yeezyrance.gif" alt="null" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important"><p><em>DBW Realty</em></p><p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Today’s <a href="https://www.dbwrealty.com/real-estate/61-nielson-rd-cody-wy-82435/10017440/115052378?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">property</a> is none other than the West Lake Ranch—3,888 acres of open land outside of Cody, Wyoming. Kanye West bought the ranch two years ago and had big plans to turn it into a Yeezy compound that could support clothing manufacturing, architectural projects, and maybe even making good music. But he decided to scrap all that and put the ranch up for sale. Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>1 bed, 2 half-baths (but plenty of room for camping)</span></li>
<li><span>Go-kart track</span></li>
<li><span>View of the Absaroka Mountains</span></li>
<li><span>No income tax and one of the lowest property taxes in the country</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much to do like the other billionaires do?</p>
</div>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">

#353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eI’m home in Western Massachusetts to see my parents for the weekend, but with all due respect to them, the real party here is the #foliage.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAt first glance, the sea of yellow, orange, red, and brown might seem like a random medley of colors...but it’s not. When chlorophyll abandons a tree in the autumn, it leaves behind a mix of other pigments that are distinct from one species to the next.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe sugar maple, which rules the fall foliage world in North America, glows a brilliant orange. Dogwoods turn reddish-purple. Beech and hickory trees get their yellow on. And oak leaves—well, most of the poor fellows fade to brown before they become raking fodder.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI like to think of it as each tree leaving its individual signature on nature's canvas before retiring for the winter.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Icebreakers With...Broadway's Jordan Fisher\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/1ba40492ff948b1eaefd5ad56f85a02c9861468e-4240x2832.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eJordan Fisher\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eJordan Fisher has appeared in TV shows since 2009, but the actor got his big break on Broadway in 2016 with a role in \u003cem\u003eHamilton\u003c/em\u003e. In December 2019, Jordan was selected to play the lead in \u003cem\u003eDear Evan Hansen \u003c/em\u003eand then...well...no one got to play any theater roles, anywhere. Now, Jordan will finally get the chance to wear his cast on Broadway starting December 11.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe caught up with Jordan to see how he’s feeling now that Broadway’s back.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTell us what it means to be heading back to live theater again with \u003cem\u003eDear Evan Hansen\u003c/em\u003e. Do you think anything will be different after being away for so long?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eJust to be in the theater again...I didn't anticipate the range of emotions that I would feel walking into a theater. I missed that energy. So I'm thrilled to be able to take the stage again for \u003cem\u003eDear Evan Hansen\u003c/em\u003e and wear that polo and wave through windows all over again.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat are the top three songs you've been listening to right now?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI've been listening to a lot of \u003ca href=\"https://open.spotify.com/artist/5rwUYLyUq8gBsVaOUcUxpE?si=gn4pq5CgTbi-6MwuCrc2ZA\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eLawrence\u003c/a\u003e. Their new album, \u003cem\u003eHotel TV\u003c/em\u003e, just came out, and they have a song on there called “False Alarms” that I've been listening to a lot. I've also been listening to “\u003ca href=\"https://open.spotify.com/track/6NoTgpadvWX0qKEK6aJYsg?si=9b8ef6e9510d47e5\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eI Feel It\u003c/a\u003e” by Jon Bellion, and “\u003ca href=\"https://open.spotify.com/track/15qKrPi4Kg0z7g9HlwWyeb?si=527dad8c9b324324\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eThe Jackie\u003c/a\u003e” by Bas with J-Cole \u0026 Lil Tjay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSpeaking of music, what's the hardest thing you've ever had to sing?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe hardest song any artist ever has to sing ever is the US national anthem. That will always be the answer. It's just very difficult. It requires a lot of you. It takes a lot of energy and it's usually a cappella, and there is very, very minimal room for error.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou’re 27 now, what are some things you wish you knew when you were 20 years old?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEverything that I know now. It's funny because everybody is either in a rush to grow up or doesn't want to grow up at all. And I feel I'm somewhere in the middle. I think that my appreciation for time as a kind of currency has grown as I age. But at the end of the day, I would never go back and tell my past self anything because everything that's happened in my life has happened for a reason. This is what has led me to this point. And I'm very happy with my life.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo, I think if I had to go back in time and tell my past self anything, it would be like, *fist bump* “Let's just keep going.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/icebreakers-with-broadway-s-jordan-fisher\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; Should I Leave? \n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/undefined?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make it work image \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI started a new job last month and they haven’t given me much guidance on what my role is. Most days I’m twiddling my thumbs for eight hours. Is it worth sticking it out to see if the environment changes?—Lily, Baltimore\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI read \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/12/americans-quit-their-jobs-at-a-record-rate-in-august?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esomewhere\u003c/a\u003e this week that 4.3 million people (and presumably 8.6 million thumbs) quit their jobs in the US this August. While “sticking it out” may not be trending right now, that doesn’t necessarily mean you should be in a rush to join the exodus.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eShort of identifying something toxic or egregiously incompatible, a month is a pretty short time period to make a judgment call one way or another about a job. There’s a decent chance your boss is trying to ease you in and doesn’t realize how truly idle you are. It’s equally possible that you’re simply experiencing lackluster onboarding and/or management. Either way, you’ll need to take the reins. You’re 30 days in—what do you expect to be doing in 60 days? 90 days? Reflect on what attracted you to this job. If there’s not a clear path to you doing those things in a reasonable timeframe, it may be time to look elsewhere.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAs you seek out more to do, be careful not to get yourself saddled with “busy work.” It’s always easier to add to your plate than to take away, so view this as an opportunity to handpick high-value tasks that interest you. Remember that a valuable work experience doesn’t always mean you’re churning out high priority emails. Especially early on in your career, it’s important to consider if there are experiences (and people) worth learning from.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBottom line\u003c/strong\u003e: Sticking it out in hopes that the environment changes isn’t the answer, but taking advantage of a chance to mold your own environment is a rare opportunity that may pay off down the line. Just promise us you’ll never get \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W6xFS-WhcRc\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etoo busy to twiddle your own thumbs\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eHave a question about work you want to ask Shane? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWrite in here\u003c/a\u003e. And remember, we're also compiling work horror stories ahead of Halloween. border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Toy Story dad hands Woody to daughter\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=375 src=\"https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-15/image-0de3da6f2944c717f2c3630413db8f393daa66b6-590x330-gif/giphy-1.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"Toy Story dad hands Woody to daughter\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-15/image-0de3da6f2944c717f2c3630413db8f393daa66b6-590x330-gif/giphy-1.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eJust over a week ago, California passed a law that requires large department stores to create \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2021/10/10/california-mandate-gender-neutral-toy-sections/6082593001/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egender-neutral sections\u003c/a\u003e with a “reasonable selection” of nongendered toys and child care items.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTo be clear: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eStores can still have boys’ and girls’ sections, but they \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003ealso\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e need to have an unlabeled section.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe woke and the anti-woke are duking it out in Facebook comments over CA’s new bill, the first of its kind passed in the US, with supporters saying that it helps counter gender stereotypes and opponents arguing it’s government overreach. But the fact is...the toy industry has been moving toward gender neutrality for the better part of the past decade—without lawmakers forcing its hand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOn the retail side:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eToys“R”Us (which is back from the dead FYI) announced it was \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/11/23/toys-r-us-gender-neutral_n_8626842.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edoing away\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e with gender signage in its stores in 2013 and deleted the “boy” and “girl” filters from its website in 2015.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTarget nixed gendered aisles and labels in 2015.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eDitto for Walmart’s aisles, except you can still search by gender online.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEven if stores leave their “girl” and “boy” signs up...they may have a hard time sorting toys into binary aisles:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eMattel has a line of \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/25/arts/mattel-gender-neutral-dolls.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egenderless Barbies\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eEasy Bake Oven started selling a silver and black version after a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2012/12/18/living/hasbro-easy-bake-oven/index.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew#:~:text=The%2013%2Dyear%2Dold%20launched,other%20boys%20from%20using%20them.\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eviral petition\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in 2012 derided the “girly” color scheme.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eHasbro launched a Potato Head family set that lets kids mash together \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/25/business/mr-potato-head-hasbro-gender-neutral/index.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enontraditional parent\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e combos.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eThe latest brand to board the genderless toy train is Lego\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLego announced this week that it would completely scrap gendering its little blocks—which already don’t discriminate between the bottoms of feet—through marketing efforts or otherwise. It based that decision on a big survey that showed girls “remain held back by society’s ingrained gender stereotypes as they grow older.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eParents of 6-to-14-year-olds took the first half of the survey, and their kids took the second half, which led to some \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2021/10/12/1045244110/lego-toys-survey-gender-bias-stereotypes?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eeye-opening learnings\u003c/a\u003e around ingrained gender stereotypes, like:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003e76% of parents said they’d encourage their sons to play with Legos, but just 24% would recommend Legos to their daughters.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003e71% of boys worry they’ll be made fun of for playing with feminine-coded toys, compared to 42% of girls for masculine-coded toys.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThese discrepancies don’t stop at the toy aisle. Parents said they’re more likely to encourage girls to cook and bake than boys, and more likely to encourage boys to play sports than girls.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eFor proponents of gender neutrality in the toy aisle, this stereotyping of what a “girl” and “boy” can \u003cem\u003edo\u003c/em\u003e limits what kids think they can \u003cem\u003ebe\u003c/em\u003e when they grow up.\u003cem\u003e—JW\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/the-toy-industry-is-becoming-more-gender-neutral\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
